body.p: My Dear Ward. I seem to be under a kind of spell when you propose anything. I am engaged on Wednesday—with my new bookBleak House (No. I published 28 Feb). in the day, and to dine at Bayswater with Egg the Painter,Augustus Leopold Egg (1816-63; Dictionary of National Biography), artist: see Pilgrim Letters 5, p. 113n. in the evening. But I will get my Sub Editor Mr. Wills to see the inventionNot identified. Ward was particularly concerned with drainage for London and supported Sir Joseph Bazalgette: see Stephen Halliday, The Great Stink of London: Sir Joseph Bazalgette and the Cleansing of the Victorian Metropolis, Stroud, Glos, 1999. with a view to some account of it in Household Words,No account of Ward or his invention appears in Household Words during the next year, though articles by Henry Morley (“A Foe under Foot”, Household Words, 11 Dec 52, VI, 289-92) and by Wills (“Clear Water and Dirty Water”, Household Words, 5 Feb 53, VI, 496-7) both concern sanitation. and (as he knows Chadwick)Edwin Chadwick (1800-90; Dictionary of National Biography), social reformer. CD supported his efforts for sanitary reform. will propose to him to be at the Board of HealthThe General Board of Health, established 1848, with Chadwick as Chairman; its statutory life ended, July 54. The new Board, established Aug 54, was chaired by Benjamin Hall (Pilgrim Letters 7, pp. 384nn, 400nn). at the hour you appoint.
